Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SI2-SSI: Open Gateway Computing Environments Science Gateways Platform as a Service (OGCE SciGaP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Science Gateways are virtual environments that dramatically accelerate scientific discovery by enabling scientific communities to utilize distributed computational and data resources (that is, cyberinfrastructure). Successful Science Gateways provide access to sophisticated and powerful resources, while shielding their users from the resources' complexities. Given Science Gateways' demonstrated impact on progress in many scientific fields, it is important to remove barriers to the creation of new gateways and make it easier to sustain them. The Science Gateway Platform (SciGaP) project will create a set of hosted infrastructure services that can be easily adopted by gateway providers to build new gateways based on robust and reliable open source tools. The proposed work will transform the way Science Gateways are constructed by significantly lowering the development overhead for communities requiring access to cyberinfrastructure, and support the efficient utilization of shared resources.

SciGaP will transform access to large scale computing and data resources by reducing development time of new gateways and by accelerating scientific research for communities in need of access to large-scale resources. SciGaP's adherence to open community and open governance principles of the Apache Software Foundation will assure open source software access and open operation of its services. This will give all project stakeholders a voice in the software and will clear the proprietary fog that surrounds cyberinfrastructure services. The benefits of SciGaP services are not restricted to scientific fields, but can be used to accelerate progress in any field of endeavor that is limited by access to computational resources. SciGaP services will be usable by a community of any size, whether it is an individual, a lab group, a department, an institution, or an international community. SciGaP will help train a new generation of cyberinfrastructure developers in open source development, providing these early career developers with the ability to make publicly documented contributions to gateway software and to bridge the gap between academic and non-academic development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: The major goal of this project was to research, develop, and operate a scalable software approach for enabling scientists in many different fields to more easily use advanced computing resources and complicated scientific software to create reproducible scientific results. The project achieved this goal. 

The project’s principal outcome is the Science Gateways Platform as a service (SciGaP.org), which is an online system that is based on the open source, openly governed Apache Airavata software framework. SciGaP middleware is implemented as interacting software components that can be distributed across multiple servers. Each component in turn is scalably implemented using a microservice architectural approach, inter-component messaging, and well-defined internal programming interfaces and data models, all of which have been described in over a dozen peer-reviewed scientific publications. 

We have thus been able to treat SciGaP and Apache Airavata as subjects for researching topics in distributed systems, cloud-native architectures, and cloud-native engineering.  All of this has been balanced with our goal of supporting operational science gateways for multiple collaborating groups that in turn support scientific research.  We have furthermore, under this award, established a highly effective education program to develop a workforce of students and early career software developers.  

Intellectual Merit: The SciGaP system created by this award provides a comprehensive and integrated approach to computer science research, open source software development, student education based on in-demand technologies, and real-world services operations. Through our involvement in other NSF awards, particularly the XSEDE project and the Science Gateways Community Institute, we have established a scalable collaboration model with a wide range of science gateway providers that is actively contributing to sustaining the SciGaP project beyond the span of this award. 

Overall, we published 14 peer-reviewed papers about Apache Airavata software and SciGaP cyberinfrastructure innovations enabled by this grant. Apache Airavata provided a foundation for our cyberinfrastructure research in developing Application Programming Interfaces and data models for science gateways; in managing user authentication, identity management, group permissions, sharing, and resource secrets management; scalable, fault tolerant job and workflow execution; and management of the metadata objects created by users of the system.  In addition, we developed a flexible, Django-based end user environment that simplifies the creation of new science gateways and provides a reference implementation for our programming interfaces. 

In addition to publications about SciGaP itself, we have co-authored over 25 peer-reviewed papers with collaborators. These papers include descriptions of specific science gateways, overview papers about open source and openly governed cyberinfrastructure software development, papers on innovations in the Apache Airavata framework, and papers on security architecture design principles for our multi-tenant system.  Finally, we have leveraged SciGaP infrastructure to support two COVID-19 HPC Consortium projects and one additional COVID-19-related gateway, all with external collaborators. 

Broader Impacts: Our project goals were not only to develop software and publish papers. We operate SciGaP services on behalf of clients, many of whom we initially assisted through XSEDE and Science Gateways Community Institute support requests as well as through our own outreach efforts. As of January 2021, we operate 40 active science gateways with a combined 4600 users on behalf of clients on the consolidated SciGaP infrastructure.  In addition, we have integrated 71 different high performance computers and clusters into the infrastructure, including every XSEDE resource, HPC systems at multiple universities, and innovative virtual clusters on the Jetstream academic cloud system.  SciGaP gateways provide access to 206 different scientific applications.  Since 2014, SciGaP users have submitted over 188,000 jobs that used 230 million computing hours.  

One of the challenges facing cyberinfrastructure development is the cultivation of a talented pipeline of developers. Given that SciGaP and more generally cyberinfrastructure are based on the much larger investments made outside academia into cloud computing infrastructure, it is difficult to hire and retain talented developers within academia. We realized however that we had access to a talented, young, international developer community through our participation in the Apache Software Foundation and our location at Indiana University. We leveraged these connections in several ways. First, we mentored 39 students as part of Google Summer of Code projects. Second, we co-instructed a graduate-level Computer Science course, Applied Distributed Systems (formerly, Science Gateway Architectures), at Indiana University beginning in 2016. Over 200 students have taken this course.  The course website is https://courses.airavata.org/, and the course GitHub repository is https://github.com/airavata-courses/. Nineteen students who have participated in the IU class or in Google Summer of Code have made contributions significant enough to earn committer status in the Apache Airavata project. Key elements of SciGaP’s operational infrastructure, including its authentication system, workflow management system, metadata management system, and Django portal content management system, are direct results of student-led projects that we have subsequently taken to production.
